awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  IPY:  POLENET-Antarctica:  Investigating Links between Geodynamics and Ice Sheets
awd_abstract_narration:
This project constructs POLENET a network of GPS and seismic stations in West Antarctica to understand how the mass of the West Antarctic ice sheet (WAIS) changes with time. The information is ultimately used to predict sea level rise accompanying global warming and interpret climate change records. The GPS (global positioning system) stations measure vertical and horizontal movements of bedrock, while the seismic stations characterize physical properties of the ice/rock interface, lithosphere, and mantle. Combined with satellite data, this project offers a more complete picture of the ice sheet's current state, its likely change in the near future, and its overall size during the last glacial maximum. This data will also be used to infer sub-ice sheet geology and the terrestrial heat flux, critical inputs to models of glacier movement. As well, this project improves tomographic models of the earth's deep interior and core through its location in the Earth's poorly instrumented southern hemisphere. 


Abstract

 

This project constructs POLENET a network of GPS and seismic stations in West Antarctica to understand how the mass of the West Antarctic ice sheet (WAIS) changes with time. The information is ultimately used to predict sea level rise accompanying global warming and interpret climate change records. The GPS (global positioning system) stations measure vertical and horizontal movements of bedrock, while the seismic stations characterize physical properties of the ice/rock interface, lithosphere, and mantle. Combined with satellite data, this project offers a more complete picture of the ice sheet's current state, its likely change in the near future, and its overall size during the last glacial maximum. This data will also be used to infer sub-ice sheet geology and the terrestrial heat flux, critical inputs to models of glacier movement. As well, this project improves tomographic models of the earth's deep interior and core through its location in the Earth's poorly instrumented southern hemisphere. 

 

Broader impacts of this project are varied. The work is relevant to society for improving our understanding of the impacts of global warming on sea level rise. It also supports education at the postdoctoral, graduate, and undergraduate levels, and outreach to groups underrepresented in the sciences. As an International Polar Year contribution, this project establishes a legacy of infrastructure for polar measurements. It also involves an international collaboration of twenty four countries. For more information see IPY Project #185 at IPY.org. NSF is supporting a complementary Arctic POLENET array being constructed in Greenland under NSF Award #0632320.

por.por_cntn:
During the past 7 years the "Collaborative Research: IPY: POLENET-Antarctica: Investigating Links between Geodynamics and Ice Sheets" project has installed and operated a combined GPS and seismic network in West Antarctica, an area approximately the size of the US east of the Mississippi River. The purpose of the study is to determine the response of the crust and lithosphere of in West Antarctica due to current and past changes in the West Antarctic Ice Sheet (WAIS) and test for movement between the several tectonic blocks that comprise West Antarctica. The IPY project combined and followed on a number of "campaign" based GPS studies, where one measures for short periods (few days to weeks) every few years, with the installation of continuous GPS stations that send their data by satellite communications on a daily basis to the NSF supported University Navstar Consortium (UNAVCO) Facility, where it is archived and openly available.
The Principal Investigator participated in equipment and installation design, and field operations. The data are currently being analyzed, not only for the geodynamic and tectonic signals proposed, but also for the measurement of co-seiemic ionospheric disturbances induced by the M8.8, 2010, Muale, Chile, and the M9.0, 2011, Tohoku-Oki, Japan, earthquakes. The project also supports continued operation of a continuous, high-rate, GPS station in the South Orkney Islands (installed by a previous NSF project) that was located in the rupture zone of the M7.8, 2013, South Scotia Ridge, earthquake on the plate boundary between the Antarctic and Scotia plates. GPS seismograms from this station made a significant contribution to understanding the overshoots oftentimes observed on GPS seismograms recorded in the epicentral areas large earthquakes, constraining the faulting parameters in the back projection solution, and also addressed questions about the overlap of the rupture zones of the 2013 earthquake with a earlier M7.6, 2003, earthquake that seemed to break the same segment of plate boundary.
